name: thalidomide
source: Hughes LD; Palmer DS; Nigsch F and Mitchell JBO. 2008 Why are some properties more difficult to predict than others? A study of QSPR models of solubility; melting point and LogP. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2008. 48 (1). pp 220?356

name: thalidomide
source: Hughes LD; Palmer DS; Nigsch F and Mitchell JBO. 2008 Why are some properties more difficult to predict than others? A study of QSPR models of solubility; melting point and LogP. J. Chem. Inf. Model. 2008. 48 (1). pp 220?356
Reason: Thalidomide contains several functional groups that influence its melting point. The base structure of thalidomide is a phthalimide moiety connected to a glutarimide. Phthalimide has a melting point around 238°C due to its rigid planar structure and capability for hydrogen bonding through the two carbonyl groups. The glutarimide moiety introduces additional ring strain and hydrogen bonding potential through its cyclic amide structure, typically increasing the melting point by about 50°C. However, thalidomide also has an asymmetric carbon which could slightly lower the melting point due to weaker crystal packing. Estimating a decrease of 10°C for this factor, the overall prediction would be an increase of 40°C from the phthalimide baseline.
